item.title: Report E-2025030032
item.description:
Report E-2025030032

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-05T18:18:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-15
  • City: CINNAMINSON
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Pitt Ohio Express
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: As the freight was being unloaded at the intermediate terminal, a pail was damaged by a forklift. The pail was immediately placed into an overpack container to prevent further release. The released material was neutralized and collected for later disposal. Due to the hazard of material, the package specifications were not able to be obtained safely.

item.title: Report I-2025010004
item.description:
Report I-2025010004

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-28T00:58:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-12-05
  • City: WHIPPANY
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: MORRISTOWN& ERIE RAILWAY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 1
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: After successfully trans loading product from rail tank car to a truck a minor leak developed at the product line valve flange fitting. To repair this the air was vented from the car and all valves and hoses. The product line hose(two hoses joined together) had been blown out prior to disconnection from the truck and only a small residue of product remained in the hose. The hose was capped off at the truck connection. The leak was repaired and all bolts were re-tighten. To test for leaks at the repair, the employee got off the car and disconnected the two product line hoses so that a pressure cap could be applied on the hose directly attached to the car so this hose would hold air pressure. The first hose off the tank car was hanging in mid air where the connection was made to the second hose. The second hose then came to rest on the loading dock that is adjacent to the tank car. The employee was holding the second hose as he was disconnecting it. As he disconnected it the hose on the dock partially slipped off the loading dock causing the residue product to be run down the hose via gravity(forming a U) and back flow up to the open connection point. The residue material(estimated to be less than a quart) came out and sprayed up and under the employees face shield and onto his face and into his eye. The employee was wearing a complete suit of protective clothing, a hard hat with complete face shield and glasses. The employee immediately got into a wash down shower which was located approximately 15 feet from the incident. Protocols were followed for wash down and for the flushing of the eye as per the emergency response guidelines. The employee removed all his clothing and changed into new clothing. As a precaution he was taken by a coworker to the hospital emergency room to be checked out. He was discharged several hours later after being examined. There was no failure on the part of the equipment or package. The cause was the second hose sliding off the loading dock and gravity forcing the material out of the hose.
